one of the biggest things that I believe
in for myself and what I tell my
patients is mindfulness meditation I'm
dr. Daniel Barone a neurologist at New
York Presbyterian Hospital an assistant
professor of neurology at Weill Cornell
Medical College mindfulness meditation
is thought to just reduce the
fight-or-flight response that the body
is producing so when you're trying to
fall asleep at night the fight-or-flight
response is not what you want you want
the opposite of that you want the
relaxed we call the parasympathetic
nervous system to activate the way I
meditate it's very simple I sit in the
dark room as quiet as I can make it
actually use earplugs and sometimes even
earphones above that sometimes I have
music sometimes it's silent and what I
do is I sit upright my hands on my lap
my feet flat on the floor and I just
simply breathe in through my nose and
out through my mouth with my eyes closed
and what I'm doing is I'm focusing my
attention that's where the term
mindfulness come from I'm paying mind to
my breathing sometimes what I tell
people to do is stay in and then out as
you're breathing in and out you can say
that in your mind or I imagine images of
air moving into my nose now through my
mouth whatever will help you to focus on
the breathing that's what I recommend
people do set my alarm on my phone to go
off after 11 or 12 or 15 minutes or so
and I just put that face down and then I
don't think about it I just close my
eyes and start meditating I meditate
every day
